thread.title: Woodside revenue cut almost in half
thread.title_full: Woodside revenue cut almost in half

title: Woodside revenue cut almost in half
text:
Gas and energy giant Woodside's revenue has been cut almost in half by sliding LNG prices. 
Woodside's revenue slumped to $US898 million in the June quarter, from $US1.68 billion a year ago. 
The main culprit was plummeting liquefied natural gas prices, though the result was also affected by lower production and the timing of shipments. 
LNG prices are linked to crude oil prices, which dived sharply in late 2014 due to an oversupply in the market, driven by US shale oil production and the OPEC cartels' refusal to cut supply. 
Woodside said the delayed slide in the price it received for its LNG was linked to a four month lag in the Japanese crude oil import price, on which the company's contracts are based. 
Japanese crude prices dropped 35 per cent during the quarter to $US64 a barrel, the company said. 
Woodside produced 20.1 million barrels of oil equivalent during the quarter, down nearly eight per cent on the March quarter and 14.5 per cent compared to a year ago. 
LNG production was down in the quarter due to an unplanned outage at its North West Shelf project and a turnaround at its Pluto project. 
The company's shares were down 39 cents to $34.56 as of 1040 AEST. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Woodside revenue cut almost in half AAP
